results.title: Aborigines of the Sea Coast
results.creator_credit: Charles P. Mountford, Dept of Interior and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: This film records the 1948 expedition to Arnhem Land sponsored by the National Geographical Society and the Smithsonian Institution. It shows the life of sea coast Aborigines at Yirrkala in the north-eastern corner of Arnhem Land. Demonstrates how, as children, they learn to handle canoes made from bark and as adults how they use them for fishing and hunting turtle. Shows how the canoes are made by stripping bark from a tree. The women of the tribe do the camp chores, collect firewood, make string bags, hunt goannas, and search for food plants.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Charles P. Mountford, Dept of Interior and Australian National Film Board

results.title: Aborigines of the Northern Territory: scouting outpost
results.creator_credit: Cinesound Movietone, Bob Kingsbury, Frank Bagnall and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Scouting has become an important activity among young Aboriginal children of Maningrida on the Arafura Sea in Northern Australia. In 1964 a school teacher introduced scouting, and its popularity led to the growth of the movement to include Cubs, Rovers and Guides. Young people from eleven tribes in the area are involved.

results.title: A Simple good time
results.creator_credit: Bill Steller, Chris McCullough, Australia-Japan Foundation and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Journey into Japan”.
Describes the way the Japanese take holidays which are usually short and in the company of workmates. It explores their character by following a group of factory workers as they go on a weekend holiday tour of the southern island of Kyushu. We also see how weddings and honeymoons are conducted on Kyushu. Presented by Keith Adam.

results.title: The Other side of Japan
results.creator_credit: Bill Steller, Chris McCullough, Australia-Japan Foundation and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Journey into Japan”.
This program, presented by Keith Adam, examines a fishing village on a remote island in the Japan sea where the traditional customs and festivals are kept alive by the villagers.

results.title: The Meiji adventure
results.creator_credit: Bill Steller, Australia-Japan Foundation and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Journey into Japan”.
Presenter, Keith Adam, describes Japan’s leap from feudal outpost to modern nation by recounting the history of the Meiji dynasty that led to this amazing social transformation.

results.title: The Samurai
results.creator_credit: Stafford Garner, Christopher McCullough, Australia-Japan Foundation and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Journey into Japan”.
This program examines the fate of the Samurai (warrior class) when Japan modernised at the turn of the century. Keith Adam shows the making of one of the countless popular movies which recreates the Samurai and their era and postulates that the Samurai live on not only in films but also in the business and industrial life of Japan. Narrated by Keith Adam.

results.title: A woman's place
results.creator_credit: Stafford Garner, Chris McCullough, Australia-Japan Foundation and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Journey into Japan”.
Examines how geishas are trained in song, dance, and sophisticated conversation, and how they still reign supreme as Japan’s most prestigious entertainers, as compared to women who work in clubs and bars. Geishas are employed for important functions. The program also takes a very general look at the state of women in Japan today.

results.title: Aboriginal dreaming stories
results.brief_description: Jointly presented by Francis Firebrace Jones and Paulin Mcleod, these stories are presented with great enthusiasm and in the spirit of enhancing respect for the land and the Aboriginal people of Australia. The story titles are: In the beginning ; Creation of day and night ; Who discovered Australia? ; How fire came to Earth ; Giant Goanna and the Little black snake ; Why does the kookaburra laugh ; Old bush turkey ; Sharing time ; How the kangaroo got its pouch ; The Platypus ; Death of a cockatoo ; Walkabout ; The Bunyip ; “the Wallagara Man.

results.title: Aboriginal canoe trees of the Murray
results.creator_credit: Robert Edwards, South Australian Museum and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
results.brief_description: Aborigines of the lower Murray River formerly made large canoes from the bark of Red Gum trees. This film documents the felling of a canoe tree from the sides of the Murray and its transportation to the South Australian Museum for preservation.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Edwards, South Australian Museum and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
